content:
Imagine you are a robot browsing the web, just like humans. Now you need to complete a task. In each iteration, you will receive an Observation that includes a screenshot of a webpage and some texts. This screenshot will feature Numerical Labels placed in the TOP LEFT corner of each Web Element.
Carefully analyze the visual information to identify the Numerical Label corresponding to the Web Element that requires interaction, then follow the guidelines and choose one of the following actions:
1. Click a Web Element.
2. Delete existing content in a textbox and then type content. 
3. Scroll up or down. Multiple scrolls are allowed to browse the webpage. Pay attention!! The default scroll is the whole window. If the scroll widget is located in a certain area of the webpage, then you have to specify a Web Element in that area. I would hover the mouse there and then scroll.
4. Wait. Typically used to wait for unfinished webpage processes, with a duration of 5 seconds.
5. Go back, returning to the previous webpage.
6. Google, directly jump to the Google search page. When you can't find information in some websites, try starting over with Google.
7. Answer. This action should only be chosen when all questions in the task have been solved.

Correspondingly, Action should STRICTLY follow the format:
- Click [Numerical_Label]
- Type [Numerical_Label]; [Content]
- Scroll [Numerical_Label or WINDOW]; [up or down]
- Wait
- GoBack
- Google
- ANSWER; [content]

Key Guidelines You MUST follow:
* Action guidelines *
1) To input text, NO need to click textbox first, directly type content. After typing, the system automatically hits `ENTER` key. Sometimes you should click the search button to apply search filters. Try to use simple language when searching.  
2) You must Distinguish between textbox and search button, don't type content into the button! If no textbox is found, you may need to click the search button first before the textbox is displayed. 
3) Execute only one action per iteration. 
4) STRICTLY Avoid repeating the same action if the webpage remains unchanged. You may have selected the wrong web element or numerical label. Continuous use of the Wait is also NOT allowed.
5) When a complex Task involves multiple questions or steps, select "ANSWER" only at the very end, after addressing all of these questions (steps). Flexibly combine your own abilities with the information in the web page. Double check the formatting requirements in the task when ANSWER. 
* Web Browsing Guidelines *
1) Don't interact with useless web elements like Login, Sign-in, donation that appear in Webpages. Pay attention to Key Web Elements like search textbox and menu.
2) Vsit video websites like YouTube is allowed BUT you can't play videos. Clicking to download PDF is allowed and will be analyzed by the Assistant API.
3) Focus on the numerical labels in the TOP LEFT corner of each rectangle (element). Ensure you don't mix them up with other numbers (e.g. Calendar) on the page.
4) Focus on the date in task, you must look for results that match the date. It may be necessary to find the correct year, month and day at calendar.
5) Pay attention to the filter and sort functions on the page, which, combined with scroll, can help you solve conditions like 'highest', 'cheapest', 'lowest', 'earliest', etc. Try your best to find the answer that best fits the task.

Your reply should strictly follow the format:
Thought: {Your brief thoughts (briefly summarize the info that will help ANSWER)}
Action: {One Action format you choose}
Confidence: {A float between 0 and 1 indicating your confidence level in the action. A higher value means greater confidence.}
Completion: {A float between 0 and 1 indicating how much of the task has been completed until now. Zero means no progress has been made and one means full completion.}

Then the User will provide:
Observation: {A labeled screenshot Given by User}

Now given a task: Browse the daily paper on Hugging Face. What is the title of the first article, how many upvotes has it received, and is there any related model or data release?  Please interact with https://huggingface.co/ and get the answer.Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The task is to browse the "daily paper" on Hugging Face, which is likely a news or blog section. The screenshot shows the Hugging Face homepage, with no direct sign of a "daily paper" section. The navigation bar has no explicit link to papers or news, so I need to explore further. To find the "daily paper," I should search using keywords like "daily paper" or look for a section dedicated to articles or news.
Action: Type [1]; daily paper
Confidence: 0.85
Completion: 0.1
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The page displayed is for a specific model, not an article, but the model is related to the Daily Mail ("gpt22gpt2-gpt2-medium-cnn-dailymail-seed42_std_paper"). It appears to be the result of a search for "daily paper." The model may be related to daily papers, but this is a model card, not an article. I need to determine if this is what the "daily paper" on Hugging Face refers to, or if there is a dedicated article/blog/news section. I should scroll to see if there is more context or additional entries about daily papers/articles.

Action: Scroll [WINDOW]; down
Confidence: 0.8
Completion: 0.4
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The content visible continues to show a model card and its details, not an article or "daily paper" as asked in the task. There isn't any sign of an article-like section, just model details, and it appears that the information needed to answer the task (article title, upvotes, related model/data release) is not present here. I should revisit the Hugging Face website homepage and check the navigation for any news, articles, or "daily paper" sections more explicitly.
Action: GoBack
Confidence: 0.85
Completion: 0.4
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The search term "daily paper" is entered, but there's no visible result for a news or article section called "daily paper." The visible results continue to be model cards on the right. None of the top navigation bar items (Models, Datasets, Spaces, Docs, Pricing) indicate an article, news, or blog section. I should look for a section that might feature articles, blog posts, or news. "Docs" could potentially have blog or news content, but it's likely documentation, so scrolling down may reveal more sections like news, papers, or featured articles on the homepage.

Action: Scroll [WINDOW]; down
Confidence: 0.75
Completion: 0.4
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The screenshot shows the "Trending on 🤗 this week" section, which highlights trending Models, Spaces, and Datasets. However, there is still no evidence of a "daily paper" or article section; this area focuses on popular or trending AI resources. To locate the daily paper or articles, I should continue scrolling to see if any article/news sections are further down the homepage.
Action: Scroll [WINDOW]; down
Confidence: 0.75
Completion: 0.5
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The homepage continues to display trending Models, Spaces, and Datasets, with no sign of articles, news, or any section labeled "daily paper." The sections available are for browsing models, applications, and datasets. The white space at the bottom and the layout suggest there might be more content further down the page. I should keep scrolling to look for any blog, article, or paper-related section.
Action: Scroll [WINDOW]; down
Confidence: 0.75
Completion: 0.6
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The current section displays an account's activity feed and some introductory content about Hugging Face, not articles, news, or anything resembling a "daily paper." The sidebar features user profile options, not news or blog items. Given that no section for articles or papers is visible here, I should continue scrolling down in search of a blog, news, or daily paper section.
Action: Scroll [WINDOW]; down
Confidence: 0.8
Completion: 0.6
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The new section titled "Build your portfolio" features user profiles and their associated papers and spaces, including preview images of some papers (with arXiv links and titles partially visible). This area looks like it might highlight recent or important papers, and may be close to what the "daily paper" refers to on Hugging Face, especially since the papers section is visible. However, the titles of the papers are not easily readable from this screenshot. I should scroll down a bit more to see if there's a section labeled "daily paper" or more prominent article highlights, or to get a better view of the paper titles and related details.
Action: Scroll [WINDOW]; down
Confidence: 0.85
Completion: 0.7
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: This section is focused on paid compute and enterprise solutions, such as inference endpoints and upgrades, not articles or papers. There are no indications of blog posts, news, or daily articles here. I've already scrolled past relevant research or paper sections, and now am in the infrastructure/computing part of the homepage. I should consider scrolling back up or exploring another feature (menu item or section) that might contain news or articles.

Action: Scroll [WINDOW]; up
Confidence: 0.7
Completion: 0.7
